study_plan_entry.title: The economics of technology policy - case studies on climate change

free_text.Learning outcomes: How can governments tackle climate change while maintaining reasonable economic growth even in the short term? How can they turn on the green innovation machine? This course takes the Climate Change "grand Challenge" as a case for studying the capacity of advanced economies to move their whole economic system towards a green growth path. The objective is to review and discuss effectiveness, efficiency and costs of the various economic and technology policy mechanisms that need to be deployed. We will analyze the centrality of economic incentives - taxes, right prices (to reflect future scarcity of goods and thereby induce technical changes); of R&D and innovation and last but not least of the improvement of operational efficiency and diffusion of existing technologies and infrastructures.
free_text.Content: 1 - Notion of Grand Challenges; Grand Challenges of different nature (going to the moon versus addressing climate changes); the heterogeneities of countries vis a vis Grand Challenges[br/]2 - The economist's discourse and rationale in favour of modest, neutral and non intrusive R&D policy; the gap between discourses and realities; how to get more "command-and-control" on the system while avoiding government failures?[br/]3 - Economic instruments: right prices, taxes, the limited efficacy of trade policy[br/]4 - R&D/innovation and diffusion policy; the various rationale (market failures, information externalities, coordination externalities) and the various instruments (subsidies, patents, prizes); the demand side policy (procurement, adoption).[br/]5 - Conclusions and results : combining carbon price with high clean-innovation R&D subsidies; mobilizing both public intervention and private initiative; acting now.[br/][br/]Students'team will take the responsibility of leading sessions 2 to 5. Reading materials will be provided to them for session preparation.[br/]
